header.title: The Book of Milianthros
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Black Magic, Grimoire Tradition

central_thesis: The book serves as a modern rewrite of an ancient black magic grimoire, channeling teachings from Milianthros and Dakmonias. Its core purpose is to provide advanced students of the occult with exclusive knowledge and practical methods for practicing dark arts, accumulating immense astral power, and navigating the unique ethics and social structures of dark magic practitioners, ensuring the survival and re-establishment of the Order of Dakmonias.

structure_content.summary: Explains the book's origin as a channeled rewrite of an ancient grimoire, 'The Book of Milianthros,' destroyed in 47 BC. The author, a 'Fifth level wizard' and channel for Milianthros, emphasizes the exclusive nature and power of this knowledge for 'advanced students of the occult' interested in the dark path. It introduces the supernatural entities Milianthros and Spitzalod, warns against harming Fifth level Wizards, and states that followers of the dark path are 'friend to all demons and spirits' as long as they don't harm high-level practitioners.

Details methods for accumulating negative occult magic power. It discusses how dark astral force concentrates in specific places and people. Male practitioners obtain power by drinking a mixture of three drops of a woman's blood and one ounce of her urine three times a week. Female practitioners use male semen (drunk orally) three times a week. It describes charging and wearing an 'AMULET OF TORBAN' (made of lead, pewter, or clay, painted with the practitioner's blood and red/black paint, charged under a New Moon). A controversial method of consuming five drops of blood from an opposite-sex person once a month is also mentioned, with historical context correcting misconceptions about vampirism and satanic cults. A less potent method involves a spicy drink with blood, pepper, tomato juice, Tabasco, and Cognac.

Introduces Dakmonias as a powerful supernatural being, 'Ruler of the North' or 'Prince of the Underworld,' who leads the Order of Dakmonias. His mark is the Black Scorpion. Dakmonias is described with specific physical attributes, favored scents, colors, days, hours, and drinks (Cognac), inhabiting icy caves. The chapter clarifies the Dark Side's existence as a necessary balance to the positive, tolerated by Spitzalod for free will, and argues against the Christian concept of evil. It asserts that dark workings can have positive effects and are judged by the Guardians.

Discusses the re-establishment of the Order of Dakmonias, which formally ceased in 996 AD. The author is instructed to refound the Order and will initiate a new head in the early 1990s. The process of petitioning to become an apprentice involves undertaking the MAGICKQUEST black magic course. The Black Scorpion mark should only be tattooed after receiving permission and seriously committing to the dark arts, as it carries great power. The chapter criticizes the lack of commitment and fragmentation within modern occultism and emphasizes the importance of learning from authentic traditions and established groups.

Explores the creation and power of 'Rings of Power,' distinct from Tolkien's fantasy but based on real magical traditions. These rings, rare and valuable, are neutral objects that embody and focus immense astral power from complex magical rituals. Ingredients for creation include three drops of blood from an initiated witch/sorcerer, three drops of blood from a girl entering puberty, and semen from an initiated sorcerer, gathered under specific erotic conditions at midnight of a New Moon in a green glass vial with a virgin's pubic hair. The ritual involves empowering these ingredients and the metal (lead or pewter) during a ceremony where participants are 'skyclad' and sexually aroused. It warns against altering the formula, as it can create a 'ring of death' that absorbs the wearer's life force. The chapter also details how a ring of power accumulates energy through sexual intercourse, magical workings, and absorption from water or other people.

Introduces Adrian, the Dark Princess, who cuts the silver cord at death, releasing the astral soul. She is depicted as beautiful, with long black hair, wearing an emerald green skirt, bare-breasted, symbolizing ancient symbols of magic power. Her favorite gem is emerald, color green, incense citrus, month December, hour 3 a.m., and moon phase new moon. Adrian's handmaidens, dressed in brilliant yellow with a yellow dot on their earlobes, bring sexual pleasure to men in dreams and accompany her to rituals. The chapter argues that Adrian's role in death provides relief and dignity, challenging Christian views of evil. It defends her empowerment of the 'ring of death' by framing death as a release and criticizes Christian hypocrisy regarding killing. Adrian is pleased when daughters are named after her and will protect them, appearing in dreams to future witches/sorcerers.

structure_content.chapter_title: DARK SECRETS OF THE MAGIC MIRROR
structure_content.summary: Explains the magic mirror as a dimensional doorway to astral realms and a scrying tool. It details a dark use: imprisoning an enemy's astral soul. This ritual involves setting up an altar with black candles, black pepper, a photo of the victim, a ritual knife, a bell, and a container with a lid, performed at 3 a.m. on a New Moon within a counter-clockwise black pepper circle. The practitioner enters the mirror astrally, finds the victim's astral soul, and physically places the photo in the container with black pepper, causing a knot in the victim's silver cord. Another dark use is performing magical operations in the 'Cavern of Darkness' on the astral plane, where spells can be set to take effect at a future time. It cautions against letting others use one's magic mirror and advises placing the Black Scorpion mark at the bottom of the mirror frame for Dakmonias followers.

Addresses the ethics of dark magic, emphasizing that the primary ethic is NEVER to take human or animal life. It argues that modern satanic practices involving sacrifice are a perversion originating from Christian traditions, not ancient black magic. Causing supernatural death of an enemy is not a violation. Another ethic is 'Do no harm, where no harm's been done,' meaning self-defense or retribution for harm received is justified. It stresses that blood and sexual energy must be 'given willingly' for magical power transfer; forced acts negate astral fire. Violating these ethics will lead to facing the Council of the Guardians.

Advocates for integrating occult traditions into daily life and family, including children. It critiques society's view of occultism as dangerous and Christians' efforts to outlaw witchcraft. The author argues that parents should teach children Old Ways from an early age to counter misinformation and that a pagan home should have a family altar for daily rituals. It also states that nudity during coven meetings or rituals, even with children present, was no taboo in the Old Days and should not be now, as it connects to astral power. It advises against blending Christian beliefs with Old Ways, stating they are incompatible. The chapter stresses commitment to occult beliefs for effective magic.

Discusses the ancient pagan practice of dedicating young girls from birth to be raised as sorceresses ('Emerald Sorceresses'), a tradition later perverted by Catholic convents. These girls, often consecrated in their first year, receive occult instruction from age four or five and undergo specific rituals to manage and harness immense astral energy build-up. This includes weekly cleansing baths with rock salt, pomegranate juice/coconut milk, and garlic, followed by anointing nipples with blessed olive oil. Monthly, they participate in a Ritual of Empowerment. They are encouraged to actively engage in spells and rituals from a young age and must wear the Triad Flame or Black Scorpion mark (painted, never tattooed) on their left breast during workings. Crucially, these dedicated children must be shielded from Christian indoctrination to avoid internal conflict.

Defines sex as a powerful magical act, explaining how sexual intercourse creates an astral cord allowing energy flow between partners for up to a year. Dark witches absorb a male partner's astral power by drinking his semen. A woman drinking an initiated sorcerer's semen three times a week gains permanent power. A sorcerer can absorb a female's astral soul through oral sex or kissing at climax. A highly diabolical use is destroying an enemy's astral soul by a witch absorbing it during intercourse, leaving the victim physically weak and mentally unstable. It warns against attempting this on initiated witches/sorcerers. Anal intercourse is presented as an act of submission to a sorcerer by a woman (or feminine male to masculine male, or lesbian to lesbian with dildo), performed in a circle of darkness, where no astral energy transfer occurs, signifying pure devotion.

Details the process of making a 'Pact with Milianthros' to obtain preferential treatment and destructive supernatural power against enemies. This pact allows Milianthros, the 'destroyer,' to inflict greater harm on enemies than they caused. The ritual involves a female volunteer having anal intercourse with a male (not the pact-maker if the pact-maker is female, nor the pact-maker themselves if male) within a counter-clockwise 'circle of darkness' with black pepper triangles, performed 'skyclad' at 9 p.m. on a New Moon. The altar setup includes black garlic, red wine, male/female candles, scented olive oil, black pepper, and aromatic pipe tobacco. The pact-maker declares their devotion to Milianthros, and the sexual act occurs, symbolizing submission. After the ritual, the participants give thanks to Milianthros and Adrian, then dismiss the powers and break the circle.

Describes a terrible curse to be used only against those actively seeking to harm the practitioner or their loved ones/clients. This curse requires the practitioner to have the Black Scorpion mark tattooed permanently on their left breast, as it is necessary for control over the powerful force involved. The ritual involves molding a scorpion from clay mixed with black pepper on a New Moon night (9 p.m. - 4 a.m.), baptizing it with candle wax while chanting an invocation to Dakmonias and Milianthros to inflict a deadly sting on the enemy. The practitioner then holds the scorpion to their Black Scorpion mark, visualizing dark magical forces flowing into it, and then imagines the scorpion stinging the enemy's 'Third Eye,' causing horrible anguish and death. After empowering, the clay scorpion is broken and discarded, as the enemy's astral body died at the moment of the sting. It assures no karmic debt for the invoker as it's a justified defense.

structure_content.chapter_title: THE DEATH OF THE DARK SORCERER OR WITCH
structure_content.summary: Addresses the disposition of a dark practitioner's body after death to preserve their black magic power for the astral realm. It mandates cremation (to free the astral soul with its power intact), contrasting it with traditional burial in salt (which neutralized power) and ground burial (which earthbounds the astral soul). An ancient black magic tradition allows the astral soul to inhabit another willing person's body after cremation by blending the practitioner's ashes with black pepper, which the recipient then ingests on food. This pact must be made and signed before physical death. It emphasizes that proper care of ashes by a trusted individual brings supernatural rewards, while neglect incurs curses.

structure_content.chapter_title: HOW TO MAKE YOUR MAGIC WORK
structure_content.summary: Explores reasons for magical failures, primarily citing lack of commitment, superficial study, and the attempt to dilute occult teachings with Christian beliefs. It stresses that occult magic is a lifestyle requiring serious study under initiated teachers (e.g., via home study courses with feedback). The author criticizes modern occultists for seeking external approval and 'craft bashing' other groups. It asserts that 'OCCULT MAGIC' should be practiced purely, not mixed with other religions, and emphasizes adherence to 'AS ABOVE, SO BELOW' and the lost second part: 'SO BELOW, IS IT ABOVE,' implying that commitment to the supernatural dictates the power received.

Reveals the secret of a personal 'Sorcerer's Sigil,' which every witch, sorcerer, or wizard possesses. The sigil is created by drawing a circle with a small triangle at each compass point, and placing one's astrological sign or glyph in the center. This sigil, when optionally signed with one's blood, serves as a unique astral fingerprint for spells, rituals, and curses. It is an exact representation of a magic circle, with the glyph symbolizing the practitioner 'inside the magic circle doing a spell or ritual.' It should be painted on the body for ritual work, or sewn onto robes, but NEVER tattooed permanently, as this diminishes its power.

Advocates for re-establishing the 'Covenhouse' as an organized, communal living structure for occult practitioners, contrasting it with the isolation of modern practitioners. The Covenhouse provides support and allows for shared beliefs, with members contributing income or household duties. Sexual loyalty to the covenhouse leader (high priest/priestess) is a key rule, preventing outside disruptions. Sexual contact with the leader is a privilege, imparting astral and magical power, and bearing magical offspring is a high honor. All money is communal property, decided democratically. The Covenhouse, originating from occult traditions, provides a vibrant family model superior to modern traditional families and is a source of enormous astral power.

A quick and effective spell for dealing with harassing enemies. A mason jar is filled three-quarters with urine and black pepper. The enemy's full name is written five times on parchment, then the practitioner's name is written over it five times until unreadable. This parchment, along with any of the enemy's hair, fingernails, blood, semen, or photo, is placed in the jar, which is then sealed. A black candle is burned on the lid for three days, and each day the jar is shaken while chanting a command for the enemy to leave the practitioner alone or face the Black Scorpion's sting. The jar is shaken daily until the attacks stop, then broken and buried.

structure_content.chapter_title: HOW TO REMOVE A CURSE THAT HAS BEEN PLACED ON YOU!
structure_content.summary: States there is only one way to remove a curse from the Order of Dakmonias: by providing three hours of intensely enjoyable sexual intercourse to the Wizard (or a sexual partner for the Wizard if of the same sex as the victim) whose 'blood' (emotional, financial, physical, or astral harm) was drawn. This act automatically removes the curse and cannot be reinstated for that specific offense. It emphasizes that the Wizard did not initiate the harm, and the offender is responsible for the 'price of sexual favors' for defense.

structure_content.chapter_title: HOW TO PROCURE THE SEXUAL FAVORS OF ONE YOU DESIRE
structure_content.summary: A spell to gain the sexual favors of a desired person. Carve out the core of an apple, place an item from the desired person (hair, photo, fingernail) in the hole, and add three drops of fragrant perfume (for a woman) or cologne (for a man). Replace the core, seal the apple with melted candle wax, wrap it in the practitioner's undergarments, and keep it in a safe place for one week. After a week, bury the apple in the ground. A variation to remove unwanted love involves the same preparation but throwing the wax-coated apple into a lake or river immediately, as this permanently removes the love.

structure_content.chapter_title: HOW TO WIN FAVOR WITH THE DARK POWERS
structure_content.summary: A complex ritual designed for advanced practitioners committed to Black Magic to gain favor and enormous power from the Dark Powers of the Astral Underworld. It requires an assistant of the opposite astral polarity (opposite sex) to sexually arouse the practitioner without climaxing, and a child of the same sex as the assistant (to provide untapped astral power). Key ingredients include a live scorpion (which becomes the practitioner's familiar, absorbing dark astral energies), black pepper, cinnamon/spice incense, an altar draped in black, and five black candles. Participants are anointed with cognac after a ritual bath of water, salt, and milk, leaving the left breast unoiled for painting a sigil of protection (black line/circle, red nipple). A magic circle is cast CLOCKWISE with black pepper over rock salt. The ritual involves invoking the Dark Powers and Dakmonias while the assistant performs sexual arousal, culminating in the practitioner's orgasm, with the child collecting semen (if male) or anointing nipples with cognac (if female). During climax, all participants visualize torrents of green light (dark energy) surging into their bodies. Afterwards, powers are dismissed, the circle is broken, and participants clean up and ideally spend the night together to balance energies, as bizarre happenings may occur.

This chapter expands on a crucial law from 'The Book of Spitzalod': 'NEVER DRAW A WIZARD'S BLOOD.' This refers to causing any harm (emotional, financial, physical, or astral) to an authentic, initiated Sorcerer, Sorceress, or Wizard. Breaking this law incurs a severe, supernatural penalty exacted by the Powers and entities associated with the attacked practitioner, even if the practitioner is unaware of the attack. It emphasizes that this protection is a matter of 'supernatural honor' for loyal practitioners. The only way to stop the punishment is by granting the Wizard the price of sexual favors. It warns against attacking fellow occultists, Christians, or non-believers, as the supernatural powers will not be mocked and will punish offenders regardless of their beliefs or lack thereof.

Encourages the reader to embrace the knowledge of Dark Arts as an important acquisition for occult wisdom, even if not practiced exclusively. It mentions 'THE BOOK OF DAKMONIAS' as the final book in the series. It reiterates that the knowledge gained provides an edge in the occult magic realm and recommends reading the other two volumes ('The Book of Spitzalod' and 'The Book of Dakmonias') available from the International Guild of Sorcery. The author offers correspondence for questions and personal visits by appointment, emphasizing the book as a 'textbook, your guide, and your working tool' that becomes charged with the reader's astral energies, and should not be loaned out.

A powerful supernatural being, 'Ruler of the North' or 'Prince of the Underworld,' who leads the Order of Dakmonias, representing the negative side of the astral force. His mark is the Black Scorpion.
A neutral force that can be channeled for dark magic. It accumulates in specific places (caverns, swamps) and people, and its negative aspect is considered essential for the balance of the universe.
An occult order dedicated to the exclusive use of the dark side of the astral force, re-established in modern times, with the Black Scorpion as its identifying mark.

A highly advanced and powerful occult practitioner who is essentially invincible to all but other Fifth Level practitioners; causing harm to them ('drawing their blood') incurs severe supernatural retribution.

A rare and valuable neutral magical object, typically made of lead or pewter, empowered through complex rituals involving specific bodily fluids and charged with astral energy, accumulating power over time, and used to direct magical workings.
A dangerous artifact created when the formula for a Ring of Power is altered or incomplete, leading to the absorption of the wearer's life force and eventual death.

A beautiful supernatural being associated with death and the Dark Side, who cuts the silver cord at the moment of death, releasing the astral soul. She is also linked to empowering Rings of Death and is depicted as bare-breasted, symbolizing ancient magical power.
A dimensional doorway to astral realms and a scrying tool, used in dark magic to imprison astral souls or perform remote magical operations in the Cavern of Darkness.

A code governing dark practitioners, primarily forbidding the taking of human or animal life (though supernatural death as retribution is allowed) and requiring willingly given bodily fluids/sexual energy for power transfer; forced acts negate astral fire.

An ancient, communal living structure for occult practitioners, offering mutual support, shared resources, and a structured environment for raising children in the Old Ways, led by a high priest or priestess, and serving as a powerful focal point for astral energy.
A young girl dedicated from birth to the practice of sorcery, undergoing specific training and rituals to manage and harness immense astral energy, eventually becoming a powerful practitioner.

The use of sexual acts, bodily fluids (semen, blood, urine), and sexual arousal to transfer, absorb, or destroy astral energy and souls, as well as to symbolize submission and make pacts with Dark Powers.

A powerful curse invoked by a Black Scorpion initiate against enemies, causing Milianthros to inflict significantly amplified supernatural harm without karmic repercussions for the invoker, as it is a justified defense.

A terrible curse invoked by a practitioner bearing the Black Scorpion tattoo, causing the enemy to suffer self-inflicted injuries or death. It requires the permanent Black Scorpion mark for control over its destructive power.

A metaphorical term referring to any harm (emotional, financial, physical, or astral) inflicted upon an authentic, initiated Sorcerer, Sorceress, or Wizard, which automatically invokes supernatural retribution.
The non-physical counterpart of the physical body, capable of astral travel and subject to magical manipulation, such as imprisonment or absorption by a practitioner.
Ritual nudity, considered essential for certain magical workings to maximize energy flow and ensure authenticity according to ancient traditions.

practical_system.description: The system is one of operative black magic focused on accumulating and directing 'dark astral energies' through specific rituals and the symbolic/physical use of bodily fluids (blood, urine, semen), empowered objects, and sexual acts. It emphasizes personal power, retribution against enemies, and loyalty to the Dark Powers (Milianthros, Dakmonias, Dark Princess Adrian). Practitioners (witches, sorcerers, wizards) are expected to be initiated, committed to the 'Old Ways,' and to integrate dark magic into their lifestyle, including family and communal living (Covenhouse). The system asserts the neutral nature of the astral force, allowing for both 'positive' and 'dark' applications, but provides specific methods for the latter, often involving counter-clockwise movements and black pepper in ritual circles.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book positions itself as a crucial and unique modern grimoire, claiming to restore ancient 'dark arts' knowledge lost since 47 BC, specifically from 'The Book of Milianthros.' It directly challenges conventional occult ethics, often equating Christian practices with historical perversions of occult traditions. Its controversial content (e.g., use of bodily fluids, sexual acts, explicit curses, child involvement in rituals) aims to provide a 'serious' and 'advanced' guide to what it defines as authentic dark magic, distinct from watered-down or 'white light' occultism. The author stresses commitment to the 'Old Ways' for magical effectiveness and the re-establishment of organized dark orders.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Advanced students of the occult' interested in 'Dark Power' and 'black magic' who are willing to discard conventional moral precepts and engage in highly transgressive practices. The book explicitly states it's for 'research only' and 'use at own risk,' suggesting a niche audience prepared for potentially dangerous or socially unacceptable magical work. It is also aimed at those seeking to empower themselves and gain an 'edge in the occult magic realm' by understanding and practicing methods not found in other contemporary occult literature.
